title: Brag time!
content:
I don't often post but I do have something to boast about this week and thought this was a good place to share! I asked for a pay rise and I got it!! A little story breakdown for you: 
A few weeks ago, I had a conversation with my boss about a colleague who was talking about other team members behind their backs. I believe she has a good heart, but something about this company makes her behaviour a bit toxic. So I (for once) stood up and said something. My boss said she would take the feedback on board. 
Two days later, that colleague was sent to a different department. My workload increased with ALMOST ALL OF HER ASSIGNED WORK. I'd been taking on bits for a while, but this was an avalanche. 
I coped for 10 days but then almost had to take time off because of stress. I decided this was enough. I was nervous about talking to my boss again and seeming like a whinge, but she'd been receptive before, and trusted me because other people had called the above colleague out as well. So I told her I was swamped. I was taking on too much already and it had only increased with the transfer. I said I'd have to spread it over a longer timeline, and then in a stroke of madness, I said I could keeping going with part of the extra workload for higher pay!! 
I HAVE NEVER DONE THIS BEFORE. 
But I was feeling inspired by you guys. 
She said she would think about it, and then the next day asked for a number! So I gave her my number and (after a little bit of back-and-forth), she accepted. 
I used all the techniques you've mentioned, like using my brag document and thinking of the number beforehand, and it worked. IT ACTUALLY WORKED. 
I'm gonna take my career into my own hands more often now. Shoutout to all of you guys for being an inspiration this past year. Good luck in your own negotiations!

title: Praise be to Martin Lewis and his car insurance tips
content:
Money Saving Expert shares tips about how and when to get your car insurance. He suggests between 20-26 days before you need it, with day 23 supposedly being the best bet (this information is just a theory from MSE and not fact, of course). 
On top of timings, MSE suggests there are different ways to include your job title that may help garner a better quote, without being untruthful.
My insurance is due in 23 days from today. A few weeks ago I looked at comparison sites using MSE job title advice just to see an average cost. It was about £380. Last year I paid over £450. I bought my insurance yesterday for £282 using MSE advice.
And the added extra that I bought via TOPCASHBACK so I’ll even get a further £25 cashback too.
I just wanted to make a post about this because it only took a few extra minutes of my time and I’m saving almost half of what my previous year’s car insurance was. The cost of living crisis is going to suck for many, but just a small reminder that taking a bit of time to research and check details can make quite drastic changes in how much you pay.
